questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of muscle weakness, fatigue, and frequent urination. Her blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. Investigations: Serum K+: 2.8 mEq/L, Serum Na+: 148 mEq/L, Plasma aldosterone: 35 ng/dL, Plasma renin activity: 0.2 ng/mL/h. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Blood Pressure

Serum K+

pH

Urine Ca2+

Aldosterone

Renin

Bartter's Syndrome

Low

Low

Alkalosis

High

Normal/Elevated

Elevated

Gitelman's Syndrome

Low/Normal

Low

Alkalosis

Low

Normal/Elevated

Elevated

Liddle's Syndrome

High

Low

Alkalosis

-

Low

Low

Conn's Syndrome

High

Low

Alkalosis

Normal

Elevated

Low

questions.text: When a nephrologist studying kidney reabsorption encounters the effects of Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) on water reabsorption, what is the most likely influence of ADH on water reabsorption?

options.label: A
options.text: Facultative water reabsorption involves glucose transporters

options.label: D
options.text: Facultative reabsorption occurs in proximal tubules

questions.correct_answer: B. Facultative reabsorption dependent on ADH
questions.explanation:
Feature

Facultative Water Absorption

Obligatory Water Absorption

Location

Distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts.

Proximal convoluted tubules and descending limb of the loop of Henle.

Mechanism

Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels via ADH

Follows solute (mainly sodium) reabsorption due to osmotic gradient.

Effect of ADH

Increases water reabsorption

Not influenced by ADH

Result

Concentrated urine when ADH is high.

Constant reabsorption rate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes is being monitored for her renal glucose handling. During the monitoring, the clinician noticed that glucose appeared in her urine even at low plasma glucose concentrations. What is the most likely cause?

A 63-year-old male complains of increased micturition, tingling numbness, and a non-healing ulcer. On examination, his FBS is 260 mg/dl, and he has glucose in his urine. What is the most likely cause of glucose in urine?
questions.correct_answer: B. Exceeded renal threshold of glucose.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic woman is being treated with medication that inhibits the reabsorption of glucose by the kidneys. What is the likely transporter inhibited by oral hyperglycemic medication, and what is its likely absorption mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Luminal transporters

Basolateral transporters

SGLT-1

SGLT-2

GLUT-1

GLUT-2

Location in PCT

In the distal part (S3 segment)

In the later part

S3 segment

S1 segment

Inhibition by medication

No

Yes

No

No

Transport mechanism

Transport of glucose from the lumen to the cytoplasm by secondary active transporter.

Transport of glucose from the cytoplasm to blood by facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female complains of muscle weakness, metabolic alkalosis and hypertension. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation of ENaC. What is the most likely condition that occurs due to a mutation of ENaC?
Which channels are not typically found on the luminal side of principal cells in the DCT?
questions.explanation:
Channel/Transporter

Location

Role

Epithelial Sodium Channel (ENaC)

  

Luminal membrane

Sodium reabsorption from the tubular lumen into the cell.

Renal Outer Medullary Potassium (ROMK) channel

Potassium secretion from the cell into the tubular lumen.

Aquaporin-2 (AQP2) water channel

Water reabsorption under the influence of ADH.

Aquaporin - Type 3/4

  

Basolateral membrane

Water reabsorption from cell cytoplasm to blood.

Na+-K+ ATPase pump

Active transport of sodium out of the cell into blood and potassium into the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the cells in the distal tubule and cortical collecting tubule is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Principal cells are responsible for sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.

options.label: B
options.text: Type A intercalated cells secrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Amiloride and triamterene act as potassium-sparing diuretics by blocking sodium channels in principal cells

options.label: D
options.text: Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Principal Cells

Intercalated Cells

Main Function

Sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion (Option A)

Acid-base regulation

Proportion

60-70% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

30-40% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

Types

                                -
  • Type A
  • Type B

Key Processes

Na+ reabsorption via Na+ channels

K+ secretion via K+ channels

Water reabsorption (regulated by ADH).

Type A: (Option B)

  • H+ secretion
  • HCO3- reabsorption

Type B:

  • HCO3- secretion
  • H+ reabsorption

Key Transporters

Na+-K+ ATPase pump in basolateral membrane.

Type A

  • H+-ATPase (apical
  • H+-K+-ATPase (apical)
  • Cl--HCO3- exchanger (basolateral)

Type B:

  • H+-ATPase (basolateral)
  • Pendrin (Cl--HCO3- exchanger, apical)

Hormonal Regulation

Responsive to aldosterone

Not primarily regulated by aldosterone.

Diuretic Targets

Primary targets for potassium-sparing diuretics

Not primary targets for most diuretics.

Specific Diuretics
  • Spironolactone and eplerenone (aldosterone antagonists)
  • Amiloride and triamterene (Na+ channel blockers) (Option C)

Not specifically targeted by common diuretics.

Effect of K+-sparing Diuretics

Decrease Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion

Minimal direct effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Gitelman syndrome?
Which of the following statements regarding Bartter's syndrome is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Caused by mutations in the sodium-chloride-potassium co-transporter in the loop of Henle.

options.label: B
options.text: Common features include hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

options.label: D
options.text: Leads to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

questions.correct_answer: C. Typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

questions.text: While flowing through which of the following segments does the filtrate become progressively hypertonic compared to plasma?
questions.explanation:
Nephron Segment

Tonicity relative to Plasma

Filtration (Glomerulus)

Isotonic (Same as plasma osmolality)

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Isotonic

  • Absorption of solute is proportional to the reabsorption of water.

Thin Descending Limb

Hypertonic (Water reabsorption, no solute reabsorption)

  • Isotonic - - - - -> Hypertonic

Thick Ascending Limb

  • Hypertonic - - - - - > Isotonic
    • (Solute reabsorption, no water reabsorption)

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)

Hypotonic

Collecting Duct (CD)

It depends upon the presence of ADH in the blood
  • With ADH, more reabsorption of water and Hypertonic.
  • Without ADH, water reabsorption is nil, which is more hypotonic.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the roles of principal cells and type A intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and cortical collecting ducts?

options.label: A
options.text: Type B intercalated cells reabsorb bicarbonate ions and secrete hydrogen ions.

options.label: B
options.text: Type B intercalated cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions

options.label: C
options.text: Principal cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions into the tubular lumen.

options.label: D
options.text: Type A intercalated cells reabsorb potassium ions and secrete bicarbonate.

questions.correct_answer: C. Principal cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions into the tubular lumen.
questions.explanation:
Cell

Channel / Pump

Side

Function

Principal Cells

(Option C)

Na+-K+ ATPase pump

Basolateral membrane

Exchanges sodium with potassium in renal interstitial fluid.

Sodium channels

Luminal membrane

Reabsorb sodium from the lumen.

Potassium channels

Luminal membrane

Secrete potassium into the lumen..

Type A Intercalated Cells

(Option D)

H+-ATPase pump

Luminal membrane

Secrete hydrogen ions into the lumen.

H+-K+ ATPase pump

Luminal membrane

Reabsorb potassium ions from the lumen.

Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger

Basolateral membrane

Exchanges Chloride with bicarbonate into the interstitial fluid.

Type B Intercalated Cells

(Option A and B)

H+-ATPase pump

Basolateral membrane

Reabsorb hydrogen ions.

Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger (Pendrin)

Apical membrane

Secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with muscle cramps and tetany for the past 2 days. Investigations reveal hypocalcemia and elevated phosphate levels. If the hypocalcemia is caused by damage to the part of the nephron responsible for the maximum reabsorption of calcium, which part of the nephron is likely affected?
Which of the following statements regarding potassium homeostasis by the renal tubule is NOT True?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum K+ reabsorption occurs in the PCT.

options.label: B
options.text: Principal cells are the major site for K+ secretion.

options.label: C
options.text: Reabsorption of K+ in the PCT depends on the daily changes in potassium intake.

options.label: D
options.text: Type B intercalated cells secrete potassium into the tubule when there is excess K+.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reabsorption of K+ in the PCT depends on the daily changes in potassium intake.
questions.explanation:
Site

Potassium reabsorption and secretion

PCT
  • Maximum potassium reabsorption (65%).
  • Does not depend on daily K+ intake.

Loop of Henle

  • About 30% of K+ is reabsorbed.
  • Potassium is cotransported with sodium and chloride.

DCT and Collecting duct

Principal cells
  • Major site for potassium secretion
  • Na+-K+ ATPase pump moves K+ into the cell from the interstitium.
  • Passive diffusion of K+ from the cell into the tubular lumen through ROMK and BK channels.

Type A intercalated cells.
  • Reabsorbs potassium during potassium depletion.
  • Mechanism: Hydrogen-potassium ATPase transporter in the luminal membrane exchanges hydrogen ions for potassium

Type B intercalated cells
  • Secrete potassium when there is an excess.
  • Mechanism: Hydrogen-potassium ATPase transporter on the basolateral membrane pumps potassium into the cell, which then diffuses into the tubular lumen.

questions.text: At which part of the renal tubule does the maximum reabsorption of sodium occur?
Where is the sodium-glucose-linked transporter (SGLT) located in the renal tubule?

options.label: A
options.text: Early part of the Proximal convoluted tubule

options.label: D
options.text: Later part of the Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.correct_answer: A. Early part of the Proximal convoluted tubule
questions.explanation:
PART of TUBULE

TRANSPORTERS

Proximal tubule






 

Early PCT (Option A)

  • Sodium-Glucose Co-transporter (SGLT)
  • Sodium-Amino Acid Cotransporter
  • Sodium-Hydrogen Exchanger (NHE)
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump

Late PCT (Option D)

  • Sodium-Chloride Cotransporter
  • Chloride Channels

Thin descending loop of Henle

  • Freely permeable to water and some solutes such as urea and sodium
  • No specific transporter

Thick ascending loop of Henle

(Option B)
  • Na+-K+-2Cl− Co-transporter (NKCC2)
  • Sodium-Hydrogen Exchanger
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump

Distal convoluted tubule (Option C)



 

 

Early DCT

  • Sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC)
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump
  • Chloride Channels

Late DCT

  • Principal Cells:
    • Epithelial Sodium Channels (ENaC)
    • Potassium Channels
    • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump
  • Type A Intercalated Cells:
    • Hydrogen-ATPase
    • Hydrogen-Potassium ATPase
    • Chloride-Bicarbonate Exchanger
  • Type B Intercalated Cells:
    • Hydrogen-ATPase (Basolateral)
    • Chloride-Bicarbonate Exchanger (Pendrin)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents with electrolyte abnormalities. He undergoes renal function tests revealing impaired reabsorption in his proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). All the following ions are reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) except?
questions.explanation:
• Sodium
  • Glucose
  • Phosphate
  • Amino Acids
  • Citric Acid
  • Potassium
  • Calcium
  • Chloride
  • Bicarbonate

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with chronic hypertension undergoes renal function tests. His glomerular filtration rate (GFR) fluctuates due to his condition, but the percentage of sodium reabsorption at the proximal tubule remains constant. This renal phenomenon ensures stable sodium reabsorption relative to GFR changes and is primarily mediated by?

options.label: B
options.text: Modulating GFR based on feedback from sodium concentrations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive thirst and frequent urination. Laboratory tests reveal hypernatremia (elevated serum sodium levels) and low urine osmolality. Further investigation shows undetectable levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). What is the location of minimum urine tonicity expected in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Descending thin limb of the loop of Henle

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.correct_answer: B. End of the collecting duct
questions.explanation:
Condition

Maximum Urine Tonicity

Minimum Urine Tonicity

In the Presence of ADH

End of the Collecting Duct(CD) / Tip of Loop of Henle (LOH)

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)

In the Absence of ADH

Tip of Loop of Henle (LOH)

End of Collecting Duct (CD)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and polyuria. Further investigation reveals a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. What is the approximate tubular fluid-to-plasma osmolality ratio expected in this patient's collecting duct?
